posts.title: ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡´ Finca PotosÃ­ from ðŸ‡¸ðŸ‡° Good Times Coffee
posts.excerpt: My very first coffee from my very first trip to Bratislava. The official start of my new hobby was a sweet omni roast from Colombia, through which I learned the french press.

content.value: Shortly after I decided to start a new hobby - coffee - in February this year, I went to Bratislava, Slovakia. I figured it would be the perfect opportunity to buy my first coffee beans. Many Google search sessions later, I decided to choose
Good Times Coffee
for my visit, a small cafÃ© and roastery with great reviews and a convenient location for my trip.

After a short discussion with the barista, where I explained how new I am to this whole coffee thing, and that I had just recently bought my first french press and grinder, she recommended this Colombian omni roast. It comes from the
Finca PotosÃ­ farm in Valle del Cuaca department in western Colombia
. The farm is situated at an altitude between 1400 and 2000 MASL and this particular coffee comes from a mix of varieties of 100% Arabica and has been dry processed.
The taste profile contains
raspberries, rhubarb, grapes, and citruses

. I really liked it, even though I'm sure it could have been prepared in a much better way than I did, considering it was my first coffee. Unfortunately, I'm also writing this up more than half a year later, so I can't say much about the coffee. I do remember I liked it, though, and I could really taste the raspberries. As hinted above, I only used a french press for this coffee.
I wanted to learn and write something more about the farm and the origins of the coffee, but unfortunately, I cannot find it anymore on the Good Times Coffee roasters' website.

posts.title: ðŸ‡ªðŸ‡¹ Dimtu Village from ðŸ‡¦ðŸ‡¹ Jonas Reindl
posts.excerpt: My first coffee from a roastery in Vienna. Also, a new method, James Hoffman's 1-cup V60 came in the right moment - finally. Very good and consistent.

content.value: I finally got to visit a specialty cafÃ© in Vienna, Austria - for my first local roast I decided to visit Jonas Reindl, one of the best-rated and most famous coffee roasteries in Vienna. What surprised me there was a relatively small range of coffees to choose from - only two filter roasts if I recall correctly - so I decided to try this
Dimtu Village
. Both we and the place were a bit in a rush, so sadly I didn't really get to discuss the coffee with the baristas.
Farmed and produced by
Aklilu Kassa
, a member of a family with a long coffee tradition, together with his son
Biniyam Aklilu
, this roast takes its name from the
Dimtu Coffee Washing Station
located in the highlands of
Western Guji, in the large Oromio region

, standing relatively high at 2150 MASL. Interestingly and sadly, I can't really work out if it is the father, with his Nardos Coffee exporting company, or the son with his new Gujoo Trading company, who is the main person behind this coffee. Jonas Reindl seems to be mixing the two with Aklilu Kassa as the farmer on the package, but focusing on Biniyam Aklilu on their website... Nevertheless, the family story is quite interesting, and locating the origin has been a challenge.
What can be said with fair certainty, however, is the washed processing used for these beans. They themselves come from the classic
mixed heirloom

variety, a common name for wild varieties in Ethiopia. Because of the altitude, these beans were smaller and the drying process takes a lot longer than usual, 22 to 25 days, due to the cold weather. The beans were also visibly smaller in the final roasted package.
My first impression was the strong fruity smell. The official taste profile says
tangerines, vanilla, and dried stone fruits

, together with the smell very much typical for the heirloom. Around the same time that I was starting with this coffee, James Hoffman published his new V60 1-cup technique, just in time for me, so I immediately tried it - with great success. It was my main method of preparation for this coffee and I really liked it, it was very consistent. When colder, I tasted the citruses (perhaps tangerines?). In the end, I ended up with a slightly finer grind (22 on my 1zpresso Q2) and I have been constantly amazed by how consistent the taste was. Nothing extra special, just a really good coffee with a citrusy finish.

An interesting observation which I have not yet confirmed officially, a lot of coffee powder stays on the inside of the grinder after grinding, as if the coffee was a bit wet - I assume this comes from the fact that it was processed using the washed method.
jonasreindl.at
algrano.com
Petra VeselÃ¡: VelkÃ¡ kniha o kÃ¡vÄ›

posts.title: ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¬ Masira from ðŸ‡±ðŸ‡¹ Taste Map
posts.excerpt: Great coffee that my best friend brought me from her Baltic trip. Very strong raisins taste, which I personally absolutely loved.

content.value: When my best friend and her boyfriend visited me in Vienna after I returned there for my last uni year, they were just coming back from a Baltic vacation and brought me this
Uganda Masira
from
Taste Map
, a multi-award winning roastery in Vilnius. Not having visited Lithuania yet, it was exciting to at least get a taste of their specialty coffee culture.
From
Mbale
, a city at the bottom of the slopes of
Mount Elgon

, an extinct shield volcano in Uganda, the coffee was grown by an award-winning farmer Dison Kareng and fermented naturally and anaerobically without oxygen in air-tight containers. It is a 100% Arabica, a mixture of three varieties - SL28, one of the most well-known African varieties, originated in Kenya but increasingly important in Uganda; SL14; and SL34, all three coming from the Scott Agricultural Laboratories from the 1930s, one of the main centers for coffee breeding in East Africa, established by the colonial British government in Kenya in 1922.
This was a great coffee, I really, really enjoyed it. Already in the beans, I could smell dried fruits, particularly
raisins
, which were also the main taste for me in most of the brews. The official taste profile includes them, alongside
plums, dried fruits, and berries
, finishing with "complex, juicy, aromatic, vinous", which goes hand in hand with the raisins.

It tasted the best during the first month since I got it when I mostly used a basic french press method. Later on, I think it got a bit more bitter and the dried fruit taste was not that strong, I then experiment a bit with some Hario V60 methods, variants of the basic 4:6 method, and I managed to get a bunch of last good brews with shorter pouring intervals (around 30 seconds). Nevertheless, I will always remember the first few cups, as I love raisins.
businessfocus.co.ug
neroscurocoffee.com
worldcoffeeresearch.org

posts.title: ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡´ Lord Voldemort from ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡¿ Beansmith.s
posts.excerpt: Washed filter coffee that we bought in the office. I didn't like that much, but it was the start of my V60 brewing and also a learning experience when I got to watch my colleague prepare it.

content.value: I spent my summer in Prague, usually in the office. Both my colleague Petr and I recently got into specialty filter coffee, so we were discussing it often, he was teaching me how to prepare the Hario V60 and together we bought and tried some interesting roasts. One of them was this one, from a Czech roastery
Beansmith.s
, called
Lord Voldemort
(apparently the farmer, Deiro Garcia, is very much a Potterhead), bought at
Kofio
This coffee comes from the
Huila
region of Colombia, said to be the place where this variety,
Pink Bourbon

- a hybrid of the Red and Yellow Bourbon, was first found. As the name suggests, the ripe cherries are pink, and the variety is quite challenging to cultivate and produce consistently. The pink genome is easily overtaken by others and the trees, therefore, have to be carefully separated from other plants.
As if that was not enough, the beans are
washed

, an interesting fermentation process that is natural for this type, done in concrete tanks for 24 hours. During the washing, the fruit layers (the skin and the mucilage around the beans) have been removed before the drying, unlike in the natural process. This should give the coffee a "cleaner" taste, focused more on the bean itself, rather than anything else in the process.
This was really an interesting coffee. The first thing you notice is the smell - very fruity. The official taste profile says
white grapes, grapefruit, and nut butter

, and the smell really hints at the (grape)fruity part. For the preparation, I used both french press and Hario V60, as this was the first coffee on which I learned the latter - and I did struggle a bit with the Hoffmann method, especially with making just one cup for myself compared with making two for me and Petr in the office.

The final coffee was usually quite sweet and tasted of nuts, but usually, I found that it smelled better than it tasted to me. I would describe the taste as "light" rather than intensive or full, but I can't say I really liked it, I didn't manage to make it in such a way I would be satisfied with it. Interesting, but confusing.
kofio.cz
gardellicoffee.com
perfectdailygrind.com
starbucksreserve.com

posts.title: ðŸ‡ªðŸ‡¹ Agaro & Jimma from ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡¿ BALANCE coffee & wine
posts.excerpt: My first espresso roast, bought on my cycling journey from Vienna to Prague. A better espresso machine would definitely make it better, but we still enjoyed it at home during the summer.

content.value: When I cycled from Vienna to Prague at the beginning of the summer, I stayed at my friend's place one night in Znojmo, a wine town near the borders of Czechia with Austria. Her sister owns a
very nice cafÃ©

(serving a delicious breakfast!) and they recently also started roasting coffee, in cooperation with the Coffeesquare roastery nearby. Knowing that I'm coming home for the summer and I could take advantage of the coffee machines we got, I opted for an espresso roast and got recommended this
Ethiopean Agaro & Jimma
As the name suggests, it comes from the town
Agaro in the Jimma Zone, Oromia region
. This one is from a small farmer
Mustefa Abakeno

, who farms at 18 hectares of land between 2000 and 2100 MASL. Mustefa set up a wet mill to process his and his neighbors' coffee, where he also naturally processed the beans that I took home. He is also able to wash-process coffee, and, with the changes in Ethiopean regulations in the last years, he has also started selling coffee directly to buyers.
Regarding varietals, this coffee is a 100% arabica, combination of the classic Ethiopian heirloom and specifically their two
sub-varieties 74110 and 74112

, which were developed at the Jimma Agricultural Research Center for resistance to coffee berry disease. The 74 indicates their cataloging year of 1974. The trees are short with small leaves, cherries, and beans, and this makes for a delicious washed coffee.
The flavor profile is quite wide with
strawberry mousse, yellow apple, ripe fig, and milk chocolate.

More importantly, however, the coffee is quite sweet and very creamy, which is something I remember very well as well. My mom found it quite sour and didn't like it, unlike me. I wasn't able to confirm any of the taste hints, but I really enjoyed this espresso. Apparently, it scored 87 cupping score points, in the "excellent" range.
gardellicoffee.com
reframecoffee.com
reframecoffee.com
spiritanimalcoffee.com

posts.title: ðŸ‡ªðŸ‡¹ Sasaba from ðŸ‡©ðŸ‡ª Bonanza Coffee
posts.excerpt: Delicious signature coffee from a Berlin roastery which I got while visiting my friend. Still using only french press, but also upgrading my grinder to the 1Zpresso Q2.

content.value: In May I visited my friend in Berlin, Germany. Knowing that one of the goals of my trip was to buy myself some next coffee to try, she recommended
Bonanza Coffee
, a chain of cafÃ©s and roasteries in Berlin, voted best CafÃ©s and Coffee Roasteries in Germany in 2022 and also distributing to Asia with branches in South Korea.
It didn't take long to choose - I went for
Sasaba Ethiopia coffee
, medium (omni) roast, probably the most famous one from Bonanza and a winning coffee of several brewers' cups and barista championships. Coming from the
Guji region in Ethiopia
, the beans are mixed local heirloom varietals, term referring to old arabica plant varietals in Ethiopia. The coffee was naturally processed in the
Sasaba Washing Station

, founded in 2005 and owned by Tsegay Hagos Tsefaye, which collects coffee from more than 500 smallholders in the Guji region, washes or naturally processes them (depending on the coffee) and then distributes the final product. The natural coffees, as was the case with this Sasaba Ethiopia from Bonanza, usually dry for 15 to 20 days.
The story of the Sasaba Washing Station is an interesting one, and you can read more about it
here
. Tsegay Tsefaye, the founder and owner, focuses a lot on the smallholders growing the coffee - he trains them regularly and pays out premiums for outstanding quality. It is located near the town of
Bule Hora in the Goji Zone in Oromia Region
. The farms are located around there as well.
Coming to the taste profile, the Sasaba Washing Station is known for several of them, with the main one being
peach
, which is also one of the profiles of this Sasaba Ethiopia coffee. However, the most significant is
milk chocolate
, which I could really taste, and the third one is
vanilla

. I have used only french press when preparing this coffee, but this was around the time when I upgraded my grinder - to the 1Zpresso Q2, an amazing one. With that, I have really enjoyed this coffee, it is still to this day the favorite one I've had, and it tasted great - especially the strong note of milk chocolate. Next time I'm in Berlin, I know what I'm buying again.
The terms that Bonanza Coffee likes to use - Unnecessarily Good and Not Your Typical - are true.
